worksheet.title: Elementary matrices

statement.p: Compute EA. What is happening to A when it is multiplied by E?

task.p: Do you think the same thing will happen when computing E times some other matrix?
We know that EI = E. But then consider EI in terms of the first two parts of this activity. So in terms of row operations, what is the relationship between E and I?

statement.p: Create a 3\times 3 matrix E' so that for every 3\times n matrix A, the result of E' A is the same as applying the row operation multiply row 3 by -4.

statement.p: Create a 3\times 3 matrix E'' so that for every 3 \times n matrix A, the result of E'' A is the same as applying the row operation swap rows 1 and 2.

worksheet.p: Matrices E,E',E'' from the activities so far are called elementary matriceselementarymatrix. As the preceding activities demonstrate, every elementary row operation has a corresponding elementary matrix.

statement.p: Determine elementary matrices E_1,E_2,E_3 so that E_3 E_2 E_1 B is the identity matrix.

hint.p: Use the connection between elementary matrices and row operations that we have discovered in this activity set. Consider carefully the order in which the elementary matrices should be multiplied onto B.

task.p: The matrix B happens to be invertible. Manipulate the formula E_3 E_2 E_1 B = I algebraically to obtain a formula for \inv{B} involving your elementary matrices and I. (The I factor is not strictly necessary, but is important for the next step.)

Suppose someone has performed a single elementary row operation on a matrix, but they have only given you the result of this computation (as well as telling you exactly what row operation they performed). How can you recover the original matrix the person started with?

Determine a general rule for the inverse of an elementary matrix of the type you are currently considering. You should be able to answer this directly, without using the method you developed in , by instead considering your answer to the previous step of this activity.
